Includes only patients with negative change scores between Year 2 and Year 0.

extracted-table.table-caption: Association of baseline MD measures with cognitive scores over time.
extracted-table.table-wrap-foot: aModel I: adjusted for follow-up time.

caption.p: Association of baseline MD measures with cognitive scores over time.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Model I: adjusted for follow-up time.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Model II: adjusted for Model I + demographic factors (age, sex, race, baseline diagnosis, education) and cardiovascular risk factors (smoking status, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes).

fn.label: c
fn.p: Model III: adjusted for Model II + risk factors for cerebrovascular disease (white matter hyperintensities, number of lacunes, number of cerebral microbleeds, total brain volume).

fn.label: d
fn.p: The beta-coefficients for baseline DTI measures in GEE analysis without the interaction terms between DTI measures and time in the model.

fn.label: e
fn.p: The beta-coefficients for baseline DTI measures at each time point (Baseline, Year 1, Year 2) with the interaction terms (DTI measure and time) in the model.

extracted-table.table-caption: Ratio of absolute mean differences in cognitive scores for Year 2 to Year 0 with the same change in DTI measures and the same profile for the other covariates.
extracted-table.table-wrap-foot: Values are presented as OR (95%CI), p values.Estimates were adjusted for demographic factors (age, sex, race, baseline diagnosis, education), cardiovascular risk factors (smoking status, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes), risk factors for cerebrovascular disease (white matter hyperintensities, number of lacunes, number of cerebral microbleeds, total brain volume) and interaction term between DTI measure and follow-up.#: For these cognitive z-score and DTI measure combinations, their DTI effects for each timepoint was non-significant (i.e., p<0.05/12 = 0.004 for domain-specific cognitive z-score, and p<0.05 for global z-score). Although some the combinations had wide 95%CIs, all had p-values > 0.05.-: For these cognitive z-score and DTI measure combinations, their p-value for interaction were non-significant. Hence ratio is 1.

caption.p: Ratio of absolute mean differences in cognitive scores for Year 2 to Year 0 with the same change in DTI measures and the same profile for the other covariates.

fn.p: Values are presented as OR (95%CI), p values.

Estimates were adjusted for demographic factors (age, sex, race, baseline diagnosis, education), cardiovascular risk factors (smoking status, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes), risk factors for cerebrovascular disease (white matter hyperintensities, number of lacunes, number of cerebral microbleeds, total brain volume) and interaction term between DTI measure and follow-up.

#: For these cognitive z-score and DTI measure combinations, their DTI effects for each timepoint was non-significant (i.e., p<0.05/12 = 0.004 for domain-specific cognitive z-score, and p<0.05 for global z-score). Although some the combinations had wide 95%CIs, all had p-values > 0.05.
-: For these cognitive z-score and DTI measure combinations, their p-value for interaction were non-significant. Hence ratio is 1.

Although some the combinations had wide 95%CIs, all had p-values > 0.05.-: For these cognitive z-score and DTI measure combinations, their p-value for interaction were non-significant. Hence ratio is 1.

extracted-table.table-wrap-foot: Logistic regression was performed with outcome binarised on the difference of cognition scores at Year 2 and at baseline, where a negative difference is considered an event.

fn.p: Logistic regression was performed with outcome binarised on the difference of cognition scores at Year 2 and at baseline, where a negative difference is considered an event.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Model I: Unadjusted.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Model II: Model I + adjusted for demographic factors (age, sex, race, baseline diagnosis, education) and cardiovascular risk factors (smoking status, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes).

fn.label: c
fn.p: Model III: adjusted for Model II + risk factors for cerebrovascular disease (white matter hyperintensities, number of lacunes, number of cerebral microbleeds, total brain volume).
